titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012. Modified by Dot Porter in 2017.

bioghist.p: In 1849, Dr. Isaac Parrish suggested that the College of Physicians of Philadelphia start a museum of pathological anatomy to preserve valuable material that might otherwise be lost to science. In 1858, Thomas Dent Mütter, retired Professor of Surgery at Jefferson Medical College, presented his personal collection of unique anatomic and pathological materials to The College of Physicians of Philadelphia. The collection now boasts over 20,000 objects. These include fluid-preserved anatomical and pathological specimens; skeletal and dried specimens, medical instruments and apparati; anatomical and pathological models in plaster, wax, papier-mâché, and plastic; memorabilia of famous scientists and physicians; medical illustrations, photographs, prints, and portraits. In addition, the Museum offers changing exhibits on a variety of medical and historical topics.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of records of the Mütter Museum. Records include: budget records (2000-2006); files related to the Lewis and Clark and Say Ahh! Exhibits; files related to the Museum's calendar, activity and accession record books (1937-1970), museum guest and visitor registers (1887-1985); catalog of the museum (1947-1949); catalog of medals; scrapbooks (1930s and 1950s-1960s); Museum statistics; photo requests (1999-2004); group tour schedules and evaluations; and a typescript of a history of the Museum, ca. 1968-1978. Also in the collection are records of the Museum Council of Philadelphia and the Delaware Valley. Records include minutes and correspondence, and some photographs of objects in member institutions (1978-1989).

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
